text:
FRAs are used by firms to hedge the risk of (remove uncertainty about) borrowing and
lending they intend to do in the future. A company that intends to borrow funds in 30
days could take a long position in an FRA, receiving a payment if future 90-day Libor
(and its borrowing cost) increases, and making a payment if future 90-day Libor (and its
borrowing cost) decreases, over the 30-day life of the FRA. Note a perfect hedge means
not only that the firm's borrowing costs will not be higher if rates increase, but also that
the firm's borrowing costs will not be lower if interest rates decrease.
